You said you would tell me how they died. On my birthday. And tomorrow's my birthday! They died fighting, didn't they? But when the soldiers
She finally turns to face him.
- you do nothing. You are a coward, aren't you?
Yes. Yes. It was your parents who were brave. I make jams.
And you've never done a brave thing in your life? He eases himself into a chair and shrugs.
Maybe there are different ways to be brave. Did you know the French have the best carrier pigeons? And this could be the difference in the war - our messages getting through. 68.
I don't want to hear about the birds.

They are released at the front and told to go home - this is all they know. But to get there they must fly over a war. Can you imagine such a thing? Here you are flying over so much pain and terror - and you know you can never look down. You have to look forward or you'll never get home. I ask you - what could be braver than that? Emilie sheds a single tear. INT. THE BARN. DAWN. Grandfather enters the barn, strokes Topthorn's nose as h passes. He sweeps aside a rug from the barn floor, to rev a trap door. Then, he opens it. Now from out of the trap door, he lifts a big ungainly object, covered in another rug. INT. FARMHOUSE KITCHEN. MORNING. Emilie comes down the stairs as Grandfather waits proudly the stove. She stops when she sees the OBJECT COVERED BY RUG.
What is that?
A present. Emilie moves toward the object that is covered.
I hope you have not bought me a disgusting dress that I then have to wear like last year.
It was disgusting?
Yes. I looked like an ugly nun. 69. Then she stops herself and turns to Grandfather with a parental rebuke.
Give me your hand. (she takes it in hers) Grandpere, we have no money. When the war is over, then you can buy me jewels and carriages. The grandfather smiles and gives Emily a hug.

Anything you say, my sweet one. Anything-you-say! You are, of course, the boss. It's just an old thing I found - don't worry yourself - leave it, I'll put it back. He leaves the room. Now Emilie is alone and she can't hel when she brings her eyes back to the object covered by th rug. She looks back over her shoulder to make sure she's being watched and then lifts one corner of the rug. Her f explodes with a gorgeous smile. She pulls off the rug tha is covering the big thing and...it is a gorgeous old sadd She runs her hand along the saddle -- can hardly believe

location: A HILL. JUST BEYOND THE FARMHOUSE. NEAR THE WINDMILL

sense_profile: to swing Emilie up and into the saddle
text: Grandfather helps to swing Emilie up and into the saddle. All at once, the Grandfather's charity evaporates.
It was your mother's. I hid it, so as not to encourage you. Emilie, I want you to ride very slowly, very carefully. And promise me you won't go far --
Of course. Okay, I promise.
To the top of the hill and straight back again.
I promise. Emilie unties her hair and tosses the red pennant to Grandfather, releasing her hair to spill down her back an shoulder. 70.
My hero. She sets off on Joey - and quickly spurs him to a gallop.

Slowly...slowly... She rides - past the windmill - and then over the top of nearby hill - she speeds over it and out of sight. Back to the hill - a sudden change of mood. An empty shot movement, no returning girl.
Emilie! Cut again to the top of the hill, then back to the Grandfather, very worried.

Emilie! Topthorn suddenly rears up - and charges off following, sensing danger. Grandfather starts to run in the directio the hill. Topthorn charging over the brow of the hill. The Grandfather running - out of breath. He hears an indistinct scream from Emilie! He reaches the top of the hill - comes over the brow - an there is not the fallen body of Emilie, which he has been fearing, but a brutal line of German soldiers - and motorbikes. It is like a line of Indians in a Western - total, alien fear. And there amongst them is Emilie, astride a panicked Joey surrounded by soldiers. Another one holds Topthorn, who b and rears, but to no avail. Grandfather starts down the h towards his granddaughter.

location: GERMAN COLUMN NEAR THE WINDMILL. THE SAME

sense_profile: to get to Joey , who is being roug led away by a German soldier
to Joey , who is being roug led away by a German soldier
text: The Germans are moving through the horses they have gathe Emilie, unhorsed, tries to get to Joey, who is being roug led away by a German soldier.
No! Let go of me! No! 71. Grandfather grabs her. She is screaming. He tries to calm down. Joey is tied up as is Topthorn. Emilie is kicking a screaming - but also desperately short of breath.
She is my granddaughter! Emilie, stop! Don't hurt her, please! Don't hurt her. A soldier roughly shoves Emilie at him. Brandt approaches. Emilie screams at him, in tears.
You don't need them! There are so many others! Emilie is still sobbing. Grandfather hugs her - in horror that she is now struggling so hard for breath.
Please, take the bigger one and leave the smaller one. You are breaking my granddaughter's heart.
The war has taken everything from everyone.
What will happen to them?
They will pull artillery until they
Francois!
- or until the war is over.
It will never be over!

You have your answer then. The motorbikes start up and drive off. The Grandfather hugging tiny Emilie as she coughs. 72. The Germans disappear up the lane leaving the old man and child bereft in the bitter cold. EXT. GERMAN CAMP. LATER. Two grooms trail Brandt, leading Joey and Topthorn toward makeshift corral.
Heiglemann - these are yours.
Yes, sir.
They look strong - should last a month or two. FRIEDRICH is an unprepossessing, chubby man. He marvels a Topthorn.
You are beautiful. But then he looks to the other horses penned nearby, hagg and weak. He turns to Joey.
It's a pity they found you. He takes the leads of the pair of them. He sighs...

Such a pity... In a strange way, there are many humans Joey meets, but a just one, the spirit of goodness and consideration for animals, joined by little echoes throughout the film. And then they go over a ridge - and we suddenly see the explanation of Friedrich's comment. The road they can see below them is the main through road of the area - and it scene of horse horror - huge, massive guns and cannons an artillery being dragged by teams of horses that are in a terrible condition. For Joey and Topthorn, this is a moment like when soldier arrived to liberate the prisoners who had been kept in Ch prison by the Japanese during World War 2. They have neve seen horses in this condition. You can see in their eyes confusion. This is a whole different world, where horses turn into creatures that look like this. 73. And it is also a vision of their future. This may be the moment the mighty Topthorn begins to lose hope. For Joey is another level of knowledge - another mighty thing he w fight through - because he always fights through. EXT. STEEP INCLINE. DAY. Friedrich leads Joey and Topthorn in the wake of THE HUGE MORSER - an elaborate 15 ton monstrosity with a six inch bore. It takes a team of six horses to haul it with a doz men pushing from behind.
Pull together! A soldier calls from the front of the heavy cannon - pull by a particularly wretched group of horses.
Halt! Halt! Stop! Lower down the hill, Friedrich waves down the rest of the column.

Stop! Stop! At the front of the Morser, one of the lead horses collap he will never get up again. Brandt steps up, pulls a revolver out of his pocket and shoots the horse dead. It has come to this. Joey, Topthorn, and all the other horses are spooked by t pistol shot. Brandt shouts to Friedrich from the road.
Heiglemann, bring up another one!
Heiglemann, bring up another horse!
That one! Friedrich begins leading Joey up the hill, but --
No, no. The big black one! Friedrich hauls Topthorn, hesitantly, while Joey watches. 74. As he reaches Brandt:
He's a good horse, sir. But if you move him up to the heavy gun, he will be no use at all. Prince is already losing condition. His leg, sir.
You have given them names?
Yes, sir.
You should never give a name to anything you are certain to lose.
His leg is not good enough, sir.
Private, you will do as you are told.

Hook him up. Friedrich has no choice but as he starts to lead Topthorn Joey rears up and escapes his groom. He gallops up the hi to the gun - offering himself up to save Topthorn. It is "Tale of Two Cities" moment - giving up his life to save friend. He bucks and rears. Friedrich turns to Brandt.
As you see, sir, this one is stronger. Brandt takes up Friedrich, and Joey's, offer -

Hook him up. As Joey is hooked to the gun, he looks back to Friedrich leads Topthorn back down the hill. EXT. STEEP INCLINE. LATER. The convoy struggles up the hill. Joey feels the dead wei of the gun. These are several tons of cast iron - almost dwarfing the horses. Friedrich notices. Together, this gr circus struggles along the pot-holed country road in the rain. 75. Joey leads the team up the incline. Each step is an immen effort. The going, over rough scree, is very tough indeed is very difficult for Joey to get a foothold on the loose ground, but his experience in Dartmoor comes into play an although he almost loses his balance several times he sta upright and hauls the cannon - Fitzcarraldo-like - over t hill. We follow his progress step by step. Friedrich watches anxiously. Soldiers strain at the sides of the gun. One throws boards under the wheels to aid in traction. As the reach the top of the hill it almost seems the effort is t much, the cannon always in danger of rolling back. Joey finally staggers over the top - it feels as though the tethers are going to snap with the strain - but at last t cannon reaches the peak, the crest of the hill. EXT. THE BATTLEFIELD. DAY. Soldiers scurry around the giant gun, preparing it.
Halt! Halt! Take the horses away!
Shell! Friedrich observes with Topthorn as a giant shell is carr to the gun's breech.
And load! The men wrestle it into place -
Back! Case! - and secure it.
Position! The barrel of the giant gun ratchets upward.

sense_profile: the big picture - line of assembled cannons of which they were just one tin part
text: And...fire! The shell explodes from the barrel. And then from another And another. For the first time we see the big picture - line of assembled cannons of which they were just one tin part. 76. Each gun recoils violently as they shoot their shells int oblivion - as soon as one shell is fired another is loade the noise is deafening - the line seemingly endless - an obscene production line of death. This is what the horses have been feeding - this massive merciless thing. Smoke wafts from the guns as we see the explosions in the distance. The sound of the explosions takes us to - EXT. BRITISH TRENCH. NIGHT. Explosions light the dirty faces of British boys in unifo one after the next. Each light fading out before the next great blast illuminates another anonymous face -then anot and then another - and then ALBERT. Hold on him for extra moments before he fades completely. EXT. BRITISH TRENCHES. EARLY DAWN.

sense_profile: in their valuables and perso belongings
text: With the barrage lifted, the British soldiers that are huddled in a low sub-trench, are ordered back on the line Andrew Easton is with Albert and he's shaken and terrifie far cry from the happy young boy we knew. A gruff sergeant (SERGEANT MARTIN) walks the trench with bucket and each soldier puts in their valuables and perso belongings. One a lighter, some money, etc.

Valuables in the bucket, lads. If you live, you'll get them back. If you live, you'll get them back. Good lads. Albert and Andrew move down the trench in a line of soldi who are given ammo belts and grenades. Albert gets his grenades and walks further along the trenches. We follow him in real time as he passes a bunch soldiers who are kneeling in the ankle deep water, a PADR giving them communion. The deafening noise of shelling al around.

Maybe it's a drill, Albie. Maybe it's a drill like last time. We keep following Albert's progress in real time - furthe there is a post box where they all put their final letter home in identical green envelopes. We see Albert's letter addressed to "Ted and Rose Narracott" in Devon. He posts in a battered metal post box. 77. An officer approaches:
Love letter?
That's my business. It is David - Lyon's son - now in charge of this small gr of men. Still arrogant - looking older than Albert in his uniform - and clearly enjoying his superior rank.
I hear you and your mate were doing bird imitations again. You gonna write a letter to your horse? Albert ignores him. Andrew can't help but giggle.
After you find your horse, I've lost my needle in a haystack, and I could use some help. David takes up a bucket and walks down the line of soldie
Anything valuable. Anyone who comes back gets to share it out.
Stay here. Albert follows David down the trench.
Remember that day me and Joey raced you in your car?
I remember you somersaulting through the air.
Who was that girl you were with?
There was a girl? Albert nods.
There was. Don't you remember? 78.
It was just some girl, I suppose. I don't recall which one. I do remember you falling on your bum in a ditch. Andrew laughs amiably. David points to him, smirking.
You see? Always entertaining, Narracott, I'll give you that. As David walks on, Andrew smiles at Albert.

You did that? You fell on your bum? Albert leaves without answering. Andrew keeps smiling unt a large shell explodes nearby. Troops surge towards their ladders as officers scream indistinct orders. Now David leads his troop through the trenches to the fro line where they stop, lean against the enemy-side wall nervously and wait - each man in private contemplation. Sergeant Martin moves along the lines, pushing men forwar
Be ready! Be ready! Let's go, men, get ready to go! Get ready to move out! Stay in position! David calls out from atop a trench ladder.

Hold your nerve, boys. Remember, it's not far to go. There's a way through. (he moves down the line) Run fast, keep your wits about you, keep your eyes open and God and the King will keep an eye on you. Company will fix bayonets! Fix bayonets! The echo of `fix bayonets' goes down the line - and every fixes the brutal shining bayonet to the end of his gun. Then Albert turns to Andrew.
You know what it reminds me of out there? 79.
What?
That bloody impossible lower field the day me and Joey plowed it. Best day of my life that was and you were there.
And this here is the worst day of my life, about to begin, and you're here cheering me on. Us two, always. And him. He nods at David Lyons, who gives instructions to another soldier.
Once you're in no man's land, go to the flanks. Stay on the flanks.
Yes, sir. David turns to Albert and Andrew.
Come on, boys, come on. To the ladder!

Stick close to the gentry, that's our ticket, yeah? We have the pluck but they have the luck. They both smile. And then the fear takes over again. Andr particularly feels as though he is on the very edge now. David urges them forward.
You, too, Narracott.

And you, too. Andrew and Albert pass by the bucket. They throw some valuables in. But a moment later, Albert goes back to the bucket and pulls something out - a worn piece of paper - unfolds it - it is the little sketch that Captain Nicholl drew of Joey the night before they left for France. He sl it inside his shirt, next to his heart. 80.

Come on, on your ladders, boy. On your ladders. In you go, in you go. That's it. Andrew turns towards a ladder. As fate and placement woul have it - he is first in line. He puts his foot on the ladder, when suddenly the Sergeant stops him.
Listen to your sergeant! He pulls Andrew aside, speaking so that everyone can hear
If anybody turns back, if any one of our boys come running towards you - you take this rifle and you shoot them dead. Do you understand?
Yes, sir! The sergeant pushes in on Andrew, private and intense.

Do you understand me? Do you understand what I'm telling you, son? You take this rifle and you shoot them dead. Understand? Andrew looks ready to cry, but manages to nod. Albert tur to him, only to be pushed back by the sergeant.
Up there, son. Up your ladder. Up your ladder to your work! Albert looks nervously back at Albert, comforting.

It's good. Andrew, it's good. Andrew! Nobody's retreating today. Andrew! Andrew! Nobody. Is retreating. Today. The COMMANDER arrives, checks the time on his AIDE's watc mounts his ladder and blows a whistle to signal the charg A BAGPIPER plays as the men go over the top. David now heads up the ladder first. Gun fire overhead, Albert steels himself, then hauls himself over the top, followed by the next man and the next. 81. Immediately machine gun fire whistles past, we hear the screams of the first men who are shot. We follow Albert. We are him. His vision. His experience. The ground is blasted, there are bodies all around him. He tries to run his feet sink into the mud. Bullets fly past him. Felled are screaming at his feet in fear and agony. Albert stagg forward. David is now right by him. They run together. Al looks round and suddenly, David is hit. He falls to the ground, screaming.
I'm shot! No! Albert instinctively goes to help. Bullets shower all aro him.

Just leave me. Leave me! Albert grabs him and drags him onwards with him - David screaming at the pain - Albert grimly determined. Shells explode around them as they stumble on. Other men are running and falling. Albert sees cover in a huge shell-ho so dives into it for a moment's reprieve from the gun fir He sits in still terror for a moment.
You'll be all right here. You'll be safe. Someone'll come for ya.
Albert. Albert, listen...
It's all right. It's all right. We're Devon boys, yeah? David looks at Albert as though seeing him for the first time.

Yeah... Albert races onward. Back at the trench, Andrew waits - terrified - and then, out of the mist step two men - heading back towards him. a third. They suddenly catch sight of Andrew waiting ther with his gun pointed towards them. They slow down - in th terror of the assault, they had forgotten that death was waiting for them if they turned back. 82. Time seems to slow down - Andrew shifts his gun from poin at one - to the other - we see their individual faces. Th are all just boys really. And suddenly, instinct hits Andrew - he charges up the ladder, and forward, firing - past the three men, towards enemy. He chooses his death instead of theirs. A sudden barrage of machine gun fire all around him. Cut back to Albert, who makes his way to the edge of the shell hole. Bullets whizz inches from his head. He looks to see a German machine gun position to his right. Bullet whizz past forcing him to duck. Andrew charges past other soldiers, ignoring their warnin

Get down! Albert continues forward to dive into another shell hole, nearer to the German line. He scrambles from shell hole t shell hole. Now he's very close to the machine gun positi Albert takes a grenade, fumbles with the pin as his hands tremble. He finally gets the pin out and he hurls the grenade at the machine gunner. We see the explosion and t machine gun stop. Albert sprints over the top again and m it all the way into the German trench. Albert runs through the trench, which seems curiously emp Albert swings round as he sees the startling face of a ga masked German holding a rifle on him. Albert readies his bayonet but the man is dead, slumped backwards against the side of the trench still upright. Albert spins round, his bayonetted rifle in front of him, ready for action, but there is only the ghostly sight of German soldiers. Albert is alone, everyone else is dead. All the dead wear gas masks. More British soldiers drop into the trench, among them Andrew. He stumbles in the mud, drops his rifle, recovers it, and races through the trench. He glimpses Albert ahead of him, stalking through the mis Andrew breaks into a smile and rushes forward, prompting Albert to whirl with his rifle raised.
Albert pauses just in time. Then he collapses against the side of the trench, overwhelmed.
Albie. Andrew grabs Albert and holds him up, embracing him. Albe can barely whisper:
We made it. We made it. A moment later, the pair of them hurry through the trench Albert spots more comrades around a corner and calls ahea Andrew.
Andrew, this way out! Suddenly ANOTHER SOLDIER leaps from a trench branch betwe them, shouting in panic.

Gas! Gas! Gas! An instant later, a gas cloud blasts through the trench. Andrew and Albert look in horror. It spreads towards them too powerful to avoid. Andrew is closest, turns to Albert with a helpless -

Albie... - before he takes the full power of it. An instant later, white, deadly cloud encompasses Albert, too... EXT. EDGE OF THE BATTLEFIELDS. DUSK. Close on hooves and boots, slogging through muddy water, several inches deep. Friedrich is walking along, leading Topthorn and Joey. Topthorn is limping. Something is wrong - Topthorn seems to be failing - he co badly, breathes strangely. Friedrich stops to check on hi An officer notices.
Hey, there's no stopping here. Keep them moving. 84.
Sir, there's something wrong. This one needs to rest.
There's no rest for them. Move them along. Move them along! Instead, Friedrich leads the horses under the cover of a bridge for a brief respite. A moment later, Topthorn collapses.

Please, please, please. Stay on your feet. No, please. No no no... Friedrich tries to help Topthorn valiantly struggling to up but finally sinks to the ground again. This time he li semi-conscious. He is dying.
Please please... Stay on your feet. Joey deeply upset nuzzles his nose into Topthorn but the drains out him. Friedrich is in panic at Topthorn's quick

Come on. Please please... Friedrich continues to stroke Topthorn's head. Joey pushe Topthorn as if to stop him falling into unconsciousness. a moment we think Topthorn will come round but he slips a and all life leaves his body. Friedrich solemnly strokes horse, knowing all is lost. Joey does not understand. He pulls at Topthorn's reins, a trying to pull him upright. Topthorn's body is inert, his head falls to the earth. Joey will not give up, he pulls him desperately not understanding that Topthorn has died. Suddenly, Friedrich looks around. Chaos - all the German soldiers stream back past their position, scrambling to g their guns and helmets. An officer charges down the bank to the bridge, screaming orders at Friedrich.

They're coming! Leave it, private! Friedrich tries to pull Joey away to safety but Joey will leave Topthorn's body. Friedrich pulls at Joey, but Joey too lost in his grief to care about or even notice the danger. 85.
Leave it! Come with me!
Go to hell! The officer nods to two other soldiers who pull Friedrich safety. As he's dragged away, he screams at Joey:

Run. Run! Run! Run! But this is all background noise to Joey's profound refus to accept Topthorn is dead. He paws at the ground next to Topthorn, a horse standing over his best friend in a fiel and he will never leave him. And then suddenly - from around a blind turn in the streambed, a huge, remorseless tank turns, heading right Joey. He bolts, galloping down the streambed, until he reaches a barbed wire barrier - a dead end. He attempts t run up the banks, but they're blocked, as well. He rears but the tank keeps advancing. The tank is about to crush Joey. He has left it too late. is about to die. But then, counter-intuitively, he runs straight towards t tank and...leaps over it - a leap he learnt from Emilie. scrambles up and over it and leaps down behind. Joey keeps on running. He is wild, frightened. EXT. COUNTRYSIDE / VILLAGE / TRENCH. THE SAME. Joey is free - in countryside - but there is blood pourin from his leg, clearly torn by his encounter with the tank runs on - it is becoming night - suddenly there are explosions to the left of him - this fast, elegant creatu simply runs through the gaps between explosions. But as he charges on - the sky lights up in the direction is heading. He is suddenly in the thick of battle. A shel explodes next to him, and he leaps entirely over a trench Another explosion sends him leaping, but not far enough - finds himself crashing downwards, and into a trench - and races through it - and finds himself charging towards a German company. Both sides are equally startled - Joey charging through a thin trench lined with German soldiers the soldiers, finding a live horse careering through them In desperation, Joey scrambles out of the trench - and on again, rushes away from the fighting... 86. But now it is very dark indeed - he is stumbling as he ru there is blood mixed with the mud on his legs. Now it is total night - fog - confusion - he jumps again. now everywhere there are potholes - the land is massively uneven - shells are exploding all around. And suddenly se in front of him barbed wire. He crashes through it - more he bursts through again - now dragging barriers behind hi the barriers tangle, pulling him up short - he flips and lands amongst even more barbed wire. He pulls and turns to release himself but it is impossibl The more he pulls, the more firmly he is trapped. He rise up, wild, magnificent, a beast fighting for his life. He is completely trapped. He cannot move. He cannot see. is in pain. He falls. It feels like an end. EXT. BRITISH TRENCH. THE SAME.
Stand to, stand to - A young soldier, a Geordie, is on look-out duty. He looks through a periscope. He alerts his colleague in his thick northern, Newcastle accent.
There's something moving.
What the hell is it?
It looks like a cow. He passes the periscope to the second soldier.
What the hell would a cow be doing out there? We see what he sees - nothing but morning mist on the sur landscape - and something strange. It is Joey in the dist
That definitely isn't a cow.
(handing over periscope) Well, what is it? 87. EXT. GERMAN TRENCH. THE SAME. We see an almost identical scene of several German soldie looking out at Joey just as the British soldiers had done
It can't be a horse. Nothing alive could be out there.
It isn't a horse. It isn't a horse. The first German looks through his periscope. We see what sees - Joey in the mist:
Yes - it's a horse. The second German looks through the periscope, stunned.
It's a horse. A third German (PETER) lowers his binoculars.
Yeah, it's a horse. EXT. BRITISH TRENCHES. THE SAME. Now all the soldiers are gathering to look out at Joey. A CAPTAIN now has the periscope.
Well, bugger me. It's a horse.
Lads, we should call him.

How do you call a horse? The Geordie starts clicking his tongue, followed by all o his comrades. They all try to attract Joey's attention wi tongue clicks. EXT. GERMAN TRENCH. THE SAME. The Germans hear the clicks and respond with a chorus of whistles. EXT. BRITISH TRENCHES. THE SAME. Now both sides are whistling. Even the captain joins in. 88. EXT. NO MAN'S LAND. THE SAME. Joey tries to rise, but remains entangled. He whinnies in pain. EXT. GERMAN TRENCH. THE SAME. Peter lowers his binoculars.
He's caught on the wire. EXT. BRITISH TRENCHES, THE SAME.
Oh sod it... Geordie climbs up the side of the trench, and waves a whi handkerchief tied to the end of his bayonet.
What do you think you're doing? Get back, do you hear me? Corporal, that's an order! Get back! Geordie, not receiving fire, is emboldened to stand up.
Listen to him, sir. We can't leave him. He waves the handkerchief to clearly signal he is no thre EXT. GERMAN TRENCH. THE SAME. The Germans look at the young soldier making his way over Man's Land.
What's he doing?
It's a trap.
No, I don't think so. I think he's trying to help. The second German cocks his rifle and starts to take aim.

Scare him back into his hole. The second German takes a shot aimed over the Geordie's shoulder. 89. EXT. NO MAN'S LAND. THE SAME. The Geordie crouches for cover, waving his handkerchief m frantically.
It's a white flag, ent it? You see the white flag!? I'm just after tending to this here horse, is all! The Georgie marshals his courage and stands again, waving handkerchief.
Get back, you stupid git! There's no fire from the German trenches. Muttering to himself, the Geordie marches forward towards Joey:

The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want, he leadeth me into green pastures, he lay me down beside the still waters... The Geordie walks very slowly across the mud - there are bodies - the ground squelches beneath his feet. He waves handkerchief as he walks. He crosses a narrow bridge that spans a flooded bomb crater. Joey, lying on his side, wrapped head to toe in barbed wi covered in mud, watches Geordie approach. When Geordie ge too close, Joey freaks out and begins thrashing about. Jo whinnies a high scream of pain, because wire is cutting i his hide in several places, and as he thrashes it cuts hi deeper. Particularly worrisome is a strand that's wrapped around his head, crossing right over his eye, threatening slash it. The Geordie calls out in a soothing voice:
Poor beastie. Poor babbie. It's alright. It's alright. Don't buck and wriggle so, you're only shredding yourself. Joey calms a little, still moving his head up and down.

You'll blind yourself. He reaches Joey and surveys the formidable tangle of wire which Joey's bundled. The Geordie soothes and at the same time gingerly tests other strands, trying to figure out w to begin. 90.
Bugger me worthless - I didn't think to bring gloves or something to cut
He stabs his hand on one of the barbs.

sense_profile: the Peter ( the German from the trench
text: There's a noise behind him, and the Geordie turns around see the Peter (the German from the trench) standing sever feet away, holding some wire cutters.
I thought perhaps you might need these. He holds out the wire cutters. The Geordie, still frightened, stares stupidly at them.
For the barbed wire?
Yeah, yeah I... Ummm, thanks. Cheers. Cheers... He reaches out and takes the proffered cutters.

Thanks. He returns to Joey, nervous about turning his back. He tr to figure out where to begin cutting. He lifts a long str of wire that wraps around Joey's neck, stretches across h shoulder and torso and around one of his front legs. He p the wire in the crux of the cutters and is preparing to s when Peter steps closer to him.
That...That's a very long strand. When you cut it, it's going to release this - He points to a wire wrapped around the wire the Geordie's lifting. Then he points to two other wires, similarly
- and this, and this, and they'll coil back rather violently, which I'm afraid will only wound the poor fellow further. 91. The Geordie nods.
You speak good English.
I speak English well. (re: the cutters) May I? The Geordie hands them over and Peter surveys the wires.
What if we cut his head free first? So he won't try to stand up and blind himself? And then -

Pity you didn't bring a second pair. Then I could cut the wire here - He points to one of the wires entangled with the strand h been prepared to cut. Peter stands and shouts in the direction of his trench.

sense_profile: into the watery crater Moments later - Peter and the Geordie kneel beside Joey , with a pair of cutters
text: All at once one, two, three, six pairs of cutters come soaring through the air and splash into the watery crater Moments later - Peter and the Geordie kneel beside Joey, with a pair of cutters. Joey is calming down again. The Geordie positions himself across Joey's body so that he's cut the wire, it won't coil back and cut Joey. Peter positions himself to be able to cut the two wires in quic succession, holding the first wire to stop it from spring back. Joey's completely still now. Peter points between Joey's eyes.

His blind spot. The cutters won't frighten him. If you could cut here, holding this wire - He points to wires that intersect the wire that crosses Joey's eye. Then he points to the wire across Joey's eye. 92.
I could -
Say no more, I'm right behind you. As they reposition themselves, the Geordie says to Joey:

And you understand what's happening, do you not, O Best Beloved? That you must lay so very nice and still. There's a lad, you're a remarkable horse, you are, helping us help you. There's a lad. There's a remarkable lad. The Geordie looks into Joey's huge eye as he and Peter ge work on their cutting. Joey returns his gaze.
So how's things in yonder trench?
Delightful. We read, we knit sweaters, and we train our rats to perform circus tricks.
Well, if ever you need any more rats, we can always send ours over. `Cause we've more than we need, strictly speaking. Besides, they scare off all the pretty girls.
Our girls aren't afraid of rats.
Big strapping German girls, eh? Kind what gives robust massages? They laugh.

Every Thursday! And they bring rum cake on your birthday. Both men smile at this while Joey is completely still; th work quickly, in concert, cutting the horse's head free o the wire. 93. Joey raises his head, gives it a shake, neighs and then s a little. The two soldiers smile at one another. Then the set about cutting the rest of the wire; it's much easier The Geordie cuts through the last wire binding Joey's leg The two soldiers help as the horse staggers upright.
Look at that horse! Look at the muscles he's got, them long legs. They're made for running, horses. Runnin' away from danger.
Running away is all they have.
Yet we taught `em opposite. Running into the fray.
War horse.
Yeah. War horse. And there he is. What a strange beast you've become. The Geordie grabs hold of Joey's halter, though Joey show sign of running. Joey is finally free. The two men look at each other.
And now?
I take him back with me, yeah?
Since I supplied the cutters, the horse is mine. This is fair, no?
In a pig's eye. He's English, plain to see.
Oh, you mean because he's so filthy?
Because he's so smart. And you're none too clean yourself. 94.
We could box. And the winner gets the horse. The Geordie smiles.
No, thanks, pet. Must be careful not to start a war. (patting his pockets:) Do you have a coin of any sort?
Coin toss?
Yeah. He takes a coin from his pocket, hands it to the Geordie, looks at it.
All right, Fritz - you're on. He flips the coin back to Peter.
My name is not Fritz - it is Peter.
Peter - I'm Colin.
You call it, Colin.
Heads. Peter spins it in the air and lets it fall into the mud. look down. Peter shakes his head, resigned.
That's the face of my Kaiser and he does not look pleased with me. The horse is yours. They collect their helmets as snow begins to blow around them.
Gone quiet, hasn't it?
Yes.
But wait half an hour and we'll be shooting again.
I'm a terrible shot, Pete, don't believe I'll ever hit the target. He hands back the cutters.
Thanks. He notices the Geordie has offered his hand, as well. A beat, then Peter shakes with him.
Cheerio, mate.
You'll take good care of him, yes?
I will.
Our strange beast.
And you take care of your own strange self. Peter tosses Geordie his cutters.
Colin! A pair of German cutters - in memory of your handsome friend from Dusseldorf.
Thanks. Peter nods, and walks back to his trench. As he goes, the Geordie calls after him:
I'll use `em back in the garden in South Shields. You keep your head down, now, Pete me lad! As he walks away, Peter turns back briefly, calling:

Remarkable! A remarkable horse! The Geordie leads Joey towards the British trenches. 96. EXT. TRENCHES. THE SAME. Joey is now in the trenches, splashing about in the ankle deep water. He seems enormous in this cramped labyrinth. is led past the broken and wounded soldiers who look at h with amazement, dumbfounded. It is a surreal image. The h where horses shouldn't be. As Joey makes his journey through the trenches soldiers excitedly gather to watch him come by, taking pleasure in saving of this single life. EXT. TRENCHES. THE SAME. We arrive at a section we recognise as the place from whe Albert set off only the night before. Sergeant Martin is there - as one man helps a wounded soldier into a medical area. It is David, hobbling and looking shell-shocked. Another wounded soldier approaches, but Martin waves him
We're full up. Move on. David is seated next to Albert, who now seems in worse condition. His eyes are bandaged and he's wheezing. Andre is nowhere to be seen. As a MEDICAL OFFICER checks Albert
The gas got him - we had to wait till morning. The medic moves to Sergeant Martin, looking stricken.
This can't be all of us.

This is all. (bellowing to the men) All walking wounded, away to the dressing station! Away to the dressing station! EXT. HOSPITAL AREA. LATER. Joey is led into the hospital area beyond the trenches. T Geordie leads him through the snowy streets. Bandaged men strewn around, wounded soldiers waiting for attention. The waiting soldiers gather to view the strange spectacle the horse. 97. At one of the dressing areas, a NURSE tends to Albert's damaged eyes. Behind him, we see Joey pass in the street, but Albert doesn't know it. Joey limps, his foreleg clearly injured. The Geordie sold stops outside a makeshift hospital. Joey looks frail and exhausted. A DOCTOR storms over from his patients.
What's this doing here?
We need a vet, sir.
There are no vets. We've scarcely any horses left.
He's cut all over, but this leg here's got the worst of it. Geordie strokes Joey as the Doctor examines him.
It's probably tetanus. It's no good.
Please, sir - The Doctor heads back into the hospital, dismissive.
I've all these men to take care of, corporal, you can see that, can't you?

Please, sir, this horse can pull through anything. The doctor absorbs his earnest appeal. EXT. INTENSIVE CARE TENT. SAME. Elsewhere, a line of soldiers waiting for medical assista are curious about what is going on. Blinded by gas, eyes bandaged, one of them turns toward the commotion. It is Albert.
What is it? 98.
It's a horse they found, wandering about in No Man's Land. (easing him back onto a
Down you go.
What kind of an horse?
Bloody miraculous kind of an horse, be my guess. Nothing makes it out of No Man's Land. Albert lies there, but can't let go of the thought:

Miraculous horse... EXT. HOSPITAL AREA. SAME. Joey stands - breathing very deeply. The Doctor touches h wounded leg. The men from all over the medical area gather around Joey concerned about their new hero's pain. The doctor looks at the Geordie and frowns shaking his he "no."
(to the doctor:) He was alive, y'see, sir, where nothing survives, so to me and me mates, to the men, sir, he's - Well, we have high hopes for him -
You should shoot him now. The Geordie is broken hearted.
Oh, but I can't.
It'd be a mercy, lad, that leg's not going to mend. The Doctor sadly addresses a nearby Sergeant.

Sergeant. Put him out of his misery. 99. The doctor nods his head towards Joey. The sergeant, SERG FRY, takes his gun from his holster, checks that it's loa He turns to some nearby NURSES, urging them away.

Ladies, if you please. Total silence from the crowd who have gathered. They thou they were there to see something wonderful. And now they that they've gathered for an execution - but can't take t eyes off it. The Sergeant waves them back.

sense_profile: breath - before he steps forward to take aim
the crowd parts - another owl whistle and
text: All right, back off. Back off. The Geordie is the last to step away from Joey. The serge draws breath - before he steps forward to take aim. Joey totally still, sensing the atmosphere. The sergeant cocks his pistol. Suddenly there is a strange owl like whistle from fifty y away. Joey looks around startled. The sergeant turns Joey's head back around, raises his pi once more. Then, the whistle again. Even the doctor notices this tim Joey turns. Slowly, the crowd parts - another owl whistle and we see Albert, his eyes bandaged - walking forward blindly - guided by the hands of the crowd. One soldier urges Albert gently.
Go on. Do it again. One more whistle.
Joey? And this time, Joey trots over to Albert. The horse nuzzl into him. Albert can't see Joey but he touches him.
Hello, Joey. Hello boy. Where you been then, hey? Where in the world you been? He strokes Joey's mane. Joey responds, becoming very stil The Doctor approaches with the Geordie. 100.
(to the Geordie:) Do you know this man? The Geordie shakes his head, no. The Doctor speaks to Alb gently; clearly he thinks he's dealing with a traumatized possibly crazy soldier.
What's your name? Albert, realizing he's being addressed, turns to the doct
Narracott, Private Albert Narracott, sir.
This is a random horse, Narracott, and too badly injured. (to the orderly) Is this man in your care?
Yes, sir.
He's not random at all, sir! He's my horse, I raised him, in Devon. Sir, look at his legs! He's got four white socks, he's brown all over - (points to his own
- and he has a white mark here - like so... He makes the shape of a diamond with his hands. The docto turns to the orderly.
Take him back.
Come on, son.
Wait! You can't see `cause of the mud. The Geordie looks around, spots a bucket of water, grabs and uses a rag to clean Joey's legs, revealing the socks. Geordie looks at the doctor. 101.
Four white socks! The doctor takes a rag himself and wipes Joey's snout, revealing the white diamond mark. The Sergeant takes this in...and holsters his pistol.
All right, break it up. Clear off, the lot of ya.
You see, sir? He's not random at all. The doctor steps up to him.
We will attend to your horse. Patch him up best we can. Treat him like the soldier he is.

Thank you, sir. With one last amazed look at Albert and Joey, the doctor returns to the hospital area. Moments later - Albert, the Geordie, and Sergeant Fry all lead Joey through the snowy street together. EXT. MESS HALL. EARLY MORNING. Sergeant Fry strides into the middle of the throng of soldiers.

Gentlemen! Gentlemen! It falls on me to give you some important news. At eleven o'clock today, in two minutes time - the War will come to an end. Shock from the troops. Strangely muted. Not the explosion emotion you might have expected. Albert enters, his eyes still red, but no longer bandaged
The King and Queen thank you for your service. We have been victorious - even if at a higher price than many of us might have imagined.

sense_profile: our brothers fallen in the field
text: When the bells ring out - and they will in a moment, for the first time for four years - let us remember our brothers fallen in the field. And thank God for the end of this struggle and victory. And, in the distance, the church bells ring. INT. STABLES. THE SAME. Joey stands tall, eating some hay, now healed. INT. FIELD OFFICE. DAY. Complete change of atmosphere. Silence. Tension. Albert stands at attention with Sergeant Fry. A severe Major is behind his desk.
I don't understand, sir.
Officers' horses only. All other horses are to be auctioned immediately.
That is a complete and bloody outrage. It's the lad's horse, sir, from Devon. He raised him up from a pup, he did. Trained him right up to the day when the army came to town.
These aren't my orders, sergeant.

You'll have to take him to market. That's all. INT. STABLES, DAY. Albert puts on a brave face as he collects Joey and leads out of the stables in silence. EXT. THE STABLES, THE SAME. As Albert comes out the men have gathered. There's a stra sense of optimism, for such a gloomy moment. The Geordie comes up to Albert and hands him a sheaf of pound notes.
We've all clubbed together. It's everything we have. There's twenty-nine pounds there. Buy him back. 103.
Does the Major know?
The Major put in ten. The Geordie flashes a sly wink.
Mum's the word where the Major's concerned. Your friend on the crutches over there - He turns to indicate David Lyons, who nods at Albert solemnly.
- even asked the Major to say that Joey was his, an officer's horse, so that he could go back with the others. Albert is amazed. He is about to show his gratitude when sergeant major shouts:

Come on, Narracott! Get a move on. We don't want to miss the show. Albert snaps to attention and begins to lead Joey out of parade ground with the other horses. As they walk off, the sergeant silently adds some of his money to the notes in Albert's hand. EXT. MARKET PLACE. DAY. The intense bustle of the market. Farmers are gathered, bidding for horses.
Seven pounds! Seven pounds there! Seven pounds! Eight pounds here! A groom leads Joey to the auction pen with other horses.
Eight pounds! Ten pounds here! Any advance? Sold! INT. AUCTION PEN. THE SAME. Albert waits anxiously, the Geordie lad by his side, as J is led into the pen. 104.
You're alright. Nobody's gonna bid more than fifteen for a thoroughbred. They want work horses. The auctioneer starts the bidding on Joey.

Next one. We start at four pounds. Four pounds. The farmers seem disinterested, shaking of heads. The bid starts. Five pounds, six, seven, now it goes slowly, eigh nine, ten. Albert looks pleased at how it's going. He fee the cash in his hand. It seems to stick on ten, then a ne hand comes up at the back of the auction - it is a nasty looking moustached man.
Eleven. Sergeant Fry scowls.
It's the butcher from Cambrai. He's been bidding for the best all morning.
Eleven. Eleven pounds. Eleven pounds.
Let me handle this, private. (he calls out) ) Fifteen, and let that be an end to it. He looks daggers at the Butcher.
Fifteen pounds.
Sixteen.
Sixteen pounds.
Seventeen.
Twenty of your English pounds. And let THAT be the end of it, my friend. 105.
Twenty pounds.
Twenty Five.
Twenty five pounds.
Twenty Six.
Twenty six pounds. The men are all looking very worried... There's not much left.
Twenty seven.
Twenty eight.
Twenty eight pounds.
Twenty nine.
And thirty.
Any advance at thirty pounds? Then, from the back, another, new French voice...
One hundred pounds. He steps to the front of the crowd, and suddenly we see w it is. It is Emilie's Grandfather.

And sir, if you bid against me, I will sell the coat on my back and bid to one hundred and ten. And if you bid against me again, I will sell my farm and bid to a thousand. Everyone looks at Albert who is devastated. Albert is reeling. He hears the auctioneer repeat the final amount brings down his gavel. 106.

One hundred pounds. Going, going, gone. The soldiers slowly disperse, leaving Albert to stare at Joey. It really is all over. EXT. THE AUCTION. THE SAME. The Grandfather finishes paying for Joey. Albert and the Geordie stand in front of the grandfather.
Sir, I'll give you all your money. Everything you paid when we get back to England. I'll give you twice -
You don't know anything about him.
Oh, but you're wrong, sir, I know everything!
Yes, you found him! I heard you found a horse in the wire between the armies -
No, I found him, he raised him - The Grandfather goes to Joey and takes his reins.

When I heard about the miracle horse, I traveled three days because I knew whose horse it was. My granddaughter's. She saved his life! He was everything to her. He pauses, briefly, to collect himself.
Where is your granddaughter?

The war has taken everything from everyone. He is all that I have left of her. The Grandfather leads Joey away. Joey pulls, firmly but n wildly, on the rein the grandfather's holding. The grandfather lets go. 107. He watches as Joey walks to Albert and nuzzles him. They a moment together. The Grandfather watches carefully. Albert puts his face right near Joey - speaks gently.
Don't be worried, boy, when I go. I won't worry over you none. Hey, I found you, didn't I, and you found me. Grandfather softens and begins to wonder about this soldi
And we'll both... we'll both know that we made it through. Now go on. He leads Joey back to the Grandfather.
We're the lucky ones. Always have been. Lucky since the day I met you. He quietly hands over the reins.
God be with you, sir. The grandfather looks at Albert, then takes the regimenta pennant from his pocket:
Do you know what this is? Albert's amazed.
It's my father's. It's his regimental pennant. How did you come by this, sir? Grandfather hands Albert the pennant.
You may have this. Albert takes the pennant and looks at it, his eyes fillin with tears.
Thank you ever so much for this, sir... 108.
(with a sigh) ... And this. He hands Albert Joey's reins. Albert turns to face him, almost mute with disbelief. He reaches for his money.
No no, not necessary. He belongs to you. That is, of course, what my little girl would have wanted. And she was the boss. Grandfather laughs, then turns and slowly walks away.
What was her name?

Emilie. (turns back with a smile) Her name is Emilie. Albert gently embraces Joey. EXT. FIELD. DEVON. DUSK. Suddenly, we are back in the village in Devon, in the fol the valley. Dusk light. A figure approaches, silhouetted against the setting sun. Mrs. Naracott gathers the harvest, then notices as the fi makes its way up the road to the farm. A man in uniform. On a magnificent horse. Mrs. Narracott meets them at the gate and we can finally see them clearl Albert and Joey. Albert dismounts and removes his cap. An instant later, M Narracott is hugging him for all that her life is worth. EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE FIELD. DEVON. THE SAME. Ted sees them and makes his way to the field gate...shaky Albert approaches, and stops a slight distance away. Ted opens the gate to stand before his son. Albert slips something from his pocket and lets it unfurl in his hand Ted's campaign pennant. Ted accepts it quietly, then offers his hand to Albert. T shake, as men. And then slowly embrace, as father and son 109. Mrs. Narracott joins them as Joey looks on - a small fami and a beautiful horse, finally home.
